article.headline: New Mexico 93, Santa Clara 59
article.story: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) -- Not even New Mexico coach Ritchie McKay could stop the Lobos from hitting 3-pointers against Santa Clara Saturday night. With the school record for 3-pointers assured and the game already a rout, McKay yelled at his players to run out the final seconds and not try to score again . Apparently sophomore reserve center Kellen Walter didn't hear him. Walter took a pass along the baseline and launched one more 3 that swished through with 13 seconds left. It was the Lobos' 20th 3-pointer of the night in a 93-59 win over the Broncos at the NABC Classic. It was that kind of a night for the Lobos (2-0), who just couldn't seem to miss. The shooting clinic came less than 24 hours after New Mexico had 26 turnovers, hit only three 3-pointers and generally stumbled into the new season with a 75-59 win over North Carolina A&T. "I think it shows a glimmer of what college basketball is like," said McKay. "From maybe not playing as well as we know we could, to playing a little too well for this early in the season." Mark Walters scored 19 points and had a career-high four 3s to lead four Lobos in double figures. Walters, who struggled last year after undergoing knee surgery for a torn ligament, had his best scoring game since a 23-point effort against Air Force nearly two years ago. "My knees are definitely fine. I'm 100 percent and I'm not worrying about anything except playing ball," said Walters. New Mexico turned the game into an early rout by hitting 13 3s in the first half. Fifteen of the Lobos' first 18 field goals were 3-pointers. "Obviously, we didn't have a plan for it," Santa Clara coach Dick Davey said of the Lobos' 3-point shooting. Davey said his defensive plan going into the game was to focus on trying to shut down the Lobos' inside tandem of Granger and David Chiotti. "We were going into the game more concerned about the interior play but they did a tremendous job of shooting the ball," Davey said. "Part of that is their ability to shoot and probably part of it is us not getting into them and creating problems. We made it very comfortable for them to shoot." Reserve guard Jeff Hart's 3-pointer with 36 seconds left broke the previous school record of 18 3s. Walter had tied the previous record with a 3-pointer with 4:03 left. Santa Clara (1-1) managed an early 8-8 tie, but New Mexico then hit five straight 3s in a 15-4 run. Danny Granger, Troy DeVries and reserve forward Alfred Neale hit three straight, Walters connected from behind the arc after a field goal by Bronco Doron Perkins and Granger hit another 3-pointer after another basket by Perkins. The Lobos closed the first half with four straight 3s, two of them by Neale and one each from Granger and Walters, who stole the inbound pass after Granger's 3-pointer. Travis Niesen led Santa Clara with 17 points and Perkins had 10, but the Broncos had no answer for New Mexico's long-range scoring. The Broncos shot 14 3s, but hit only two. Not that the Lobos needed any help, but Santa Clara went 6 1/2 minutes without a field goal late in the first half and had only three field goals through the first 10 minutes of the second half. "This game was won on the (defensive) end of the floor," said McKay. "We just did a great job defensively." Granger hit five 3s, Neale had four, all in the first half, and DeVries hit three. Granger finished with 18 points, Neale scored 16 and DeVries 12. The previous 3-point record was set in December of 1997 against Holy Cross and tied later that season against Texas-El Paso. New Mexico, for the game, hit 20 of 35 3s and overall shot 56 percent from the field.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
